There's a new dragon book by Ann McCaffrey that I'll start reading soon.
I've got another year's best horror stories cover to do next month, or this month actually.
April anyway.
What month are we in here?
There are so many things going on, it's really hard for me to remember them all.
There's the final Fuzzing manuscript by HP, HP Lovecraft, HP and Piper.
I am wrapping up a children's book, my first children's book.
That's a collaboration with another artist named David Wenzel.
It should be a real nice book.
Let me think, we're doing...
I've got a stack of manuscripts in my studio that's probably five feet high.
They come in and I say, well, that looks like a fun one to do.
I can fit in my schedule and then I put it in the pile and forget about it
until I get done with the painting before that one is due and pick up the manuscript and say, oh yeah, this one.
I've forgotten what and all my projects are.
I've done books as much as a year in advance at any particular time.
That certainly is the situation now.
I remember, there's some of them that I remember.
Those are the ongoing projects in the Dragon one because I've got a special interest in it.
McCaffrey's work, but that's all I think of off the top of my head.
How many projects do you have going on at one time? Paintings?
I usually like to keep it to just one.
I hate to divide my interest between one painting and another project.
I go to Great Lanks to maintain a mood throughout a painting.
I did a painting that took place on a sandy planet, for example, it was all desert.
I recorded a six hour tape of all wind noises and like wind in the desert.
I just played that while I was painting the painting because I wanted to keep in the mood
and the feeling of that book and that painting.
I'd hate to be in the middle of that planet and that scene and trying to develop this environment
and then have to break it into a painting of something horrible or something, or whatever.
But it's sometimes a force too and it's happened a couple of times.
But I'm usually good enough at juggling my schedule around so I don't have to.
It is very beneficial sometimes to have a break after doing all the sketches.
I've sent the sketches into the publisher and they're looking those over for me to do another project
because when the sketches come back to me I see them with a fresh eye.
Even though the publisher may have picked one particular one, I may find a different one
that I think it really is better for the book after all and I'll throw the other ones aside.
I'll talk it over with the publisher and we'll figure out a way to compromise on them or something.
Or they'll let me go ahead and do the one I want to do.
But that is good to have a break between going through all the analyzing, the collating,
and doing the sketches before doing the final painting is good to have a break in there.
While I'm actually doing the big rendering, I hate to have to break that into another one.
That's one of the reasons why I have a strong dislike for advertising work.
Advertising work always involves having to do extra work on a painting.
You do a piece, it's the only time that ever happens to me, never happens to me with paperback covers.
I get something sent back to me for changes.
But I'll do an advertising job.
Well, advertising jobs are almost always judged by committee.
Men in the advertising company and someone always has to come up with an idea
that makes it sound like he's worth being hired to work in this company.
So if a piece of artwork gets passed around for a particular client, they'll look at it and they'll say,
well, I think this and everyone's got to have an idea.
And some of the ideas are the most stupid things I've ever heard in my life.
I'll tell you, working for advertising companies are really something.
And don't think of anything to put in, to have some input in this particular committee meeting about my piece of work
or any artist's piece of work.
I don't know any artist that doesn't have things sent back from advertising agencies and stuff on a regular basis.
And so I'll be working out, I will finish the painting, send it into an ad company or whatever.
I'll be on the next one and then the thing will come back to me because I want changes here
or brighten up this or take this out or whatever.
Then I'll have to stop and work on that other one to make the changes and send that back in.
Then I can go back to the painting I was working on.
And I hate that so much.
That's why I avoid doing a lot of advertising job.
I mean, I charge them for the extra work and all that.
And that kind of discourages them from sending it back to me.
But a lot of times it doesn't.
Let's get into glass, onion graphics a little bit.
Why did you decide to open that up?
It was a gradual process.
I'd always wanted to make prints of my work available.
Most of my work sells for pretty high prices and fans simply can't afford it.
And when I go to a convention, I like to have something that they can afford to buy.
And the way around that is by doing prints and posters of my work.
Glass, onion graphics was created to fill that need.
Now my wife has helped me out a lot by doing my bookkeeping, for example, and other things.
She stopped doing what she was doing in order to help me out in my business to a certain extent.
And glass, onion graphics was kind of an extension of that.
I said, if you want to go ahead and make a print of my work, I'd be really happy.
You can take all the profit and everything, as long as we have print available for fans to buy or whatever.
And she's turned it into a full-scale business.
Now she's so busy, she doesn't have time to do my bookkeeping and all this other stuff that we originally were going to do.
We've had to hire extra people, we have a secretary and whatever.
But now it's grown into a full-scale business.
